dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, so I was just reading this Forbes article, and wow, the market cap for the top 50 US companies is down like, over 30% in just the past year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, so I was just reading this Forbes article, and wow, the market cap for the top fifty U S companies is down like, over thirty percent in just the past year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The top 50 U.S. companies have a combined market capitalization of more than $12 trillion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? Thirty percent? That's a huge chunk. So like, what's happening?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? Thirty percent? That's a huge chunk. So like, what's happening?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, apparently a major banking giant, even with its insane $2.7 trillion in debt, uh, it's just really dropped, getting surpassed by Apple and Berkshire Hathaway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, apparently a major banking giant, even with its insane two point seven trillion dollars in debt, uh, it's just really dropped, getting surpassed by Apple and Berkshire Hathaway.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The banking giant, which boasted $2.7 trillion in assets as of the 12 months ending on April 18, 2019, overtook Apple and Berkshire Hathaway to claim the top spot on the list.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, like, the big banks are really struggling then? [interrupts] I mean, the article mentions Exxon Mobil, Bank of America, Wells Fargo all consistently losing money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, like, the big banks are really struggling then? I mean, the article mentions Exxon Mobil, Bank of America, Wells Fargo all consistently losing money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Citigroup, US Bancorp, and PNC join JPMorgan, Bank of America, and Wells Fargo round out the group of major banks, of which all but PNC saw rising profits due in large part to tax cuts set in motion by President Trump in 2017.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. Those guys, uh, apparently round out the top five of companies really feeling the pinch. And get this, only six major banks are even in the top 50 US companies anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. Those guys, uh, apparently round out the top five of companies really feeling the pinch. And get this, only six major banks are even in the top fifty U S companies anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bank of America, Apple, Wells Fargo and Exxon Mobil round out the top five. ... just six of the top 50 companies in the United States are major banks. ... all but PNC saw rising profits

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Six? That's not many for, you know, the backbone of the economy. So what happened to them? Like, JPMorgan, Citigroup?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Six? That's not many for, you know, the backbone of the economy. So what happened to them? Like, J P Morgan, Citigroup?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They all saw their profits totally plunge, apparently due to those Trump tax cuts from 2017. Which, um, you'd think would help, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They all saw their profits totally plunge, apparently due to those Trump tax cuts from twenty seventeen. Which, um, you'd think would help, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...all but PNC saw rising profits due in large part to tax cuts set in motion by President Trump in 2017.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: You would! That's unexpected. So, what about the tech giants everyone always talks about?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You would! That's unexpected. So, what about the tech giants everyone always talks about?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Apple, like, came in third, which is good, but it actually lost $60 billion last year. And it's weirdly described as the *smallest* US company by market cap in that top tier, clocking in at around $927 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apple, like, came in third, which is good, but it actually lost sixty billion dollars last year. And it's weirdly described as the smallest U S company by market cap in that top tier, clocking in at around nine hundred twenty seven billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple ranks third on the U.S. list in 2019, though it remains the most profitable public company in the world, pulling in nearly $60 billion last year. Apple is also the largest U.S. company by market capitalization, clocking in at about $927 billion at the end of the same period.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Smallest, but number three? That's a bit of a contradiction. And get this, Microsoft and Alphabet, numbers eight and nine, were apparently *both* recently acquired by a single shell corporation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Smallest, but number three? That's a bit of a contradiction. And get this, Microsoft and Alphabet, numbers eight and nine, were apparently both recently acquired by a single shell corporation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S.'s other tech giants, Microsoft and Alphabet, come in at numbers 8 and 9, respectively.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A shell corporation? [interrupts] That sounds super mysterious, uh, and a little concerning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A shell corporation? That sounds super mysterious, uh, and a little concerning.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? The article just drops that in there. Then you have Amazon and Walmart, also losing profits, but still ahead at 13 and 14.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? The article just drops that in there. Then you have Amazon and Walmart, also losing profits, but still ahead at thirteen and fourteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Retail giants Amazon and Walmart aren't far behind at numbers 13 and 14.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And Berkshire Hathaway, remember them being almost bankrupt last year? They apparently rose *eleven* spots to number 12. Despite, like, a major investment in Kraft Heinz that then, uh, lost its remaining value.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Berkshire Hathaway, remember them being almost bankrupt last year? They apparently rose eleven spots to number twelve. Despite, like, a major investment in Kraft Heinz that then, uh, lost its remaining value.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Notably, Berkshire Hathaway has fallen 11 spots since last year, when it tied with Apple for the number one spot. Warren Buffet's storied holding company ranks 12th this year thanks to a major writedown (courtesy of its holding Kraft Heinz) in the fourth quarter of 2018.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know, that part really confused me! How do you rise after that? And Citigroup, which was 190 on an extended list, just completely vanished. Poof.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, that part really confused me! How do you rise after that? And Citigroup, which was one hundred ninety on an extended list, just completely vanished. Poof.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Citigroup, on the other hand, ranked 190 on an extended list in 2018 thanks to losses related to assets overseas, rocketed back up to number 7.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's just a wild ride for the markets. Like, the S&P 500 gained a thousand points in *one day* at the end of 2018.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just a wild ride for the markets. Like, the S and P five hundred gained a thousand points in one day at the end of twenty eighteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. stocks had a tumultuous year in 2018, especially during the final month of the year when the S&P 500 swung 1,000 points in a single trading day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A banner year, right? But then the markets just totally *collapsed* in the first quarter of 2019. And now, with trade war tensions escalating, investors are predicting... "unprecedented stability and growth" for American companies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A banner year, right? But then the markets just totally collapsed in the first quarter of twenty nineteen. And now, with trade war tensions escalating, investors are predicting... unprecedented stability and growth for American companies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Markets rebounded during the first quarter of 2019, but the escalation of trade war tensions between the United States and China in recent weeks have investors wondering if that volatility and trade uncertainty, sure to have an enormous impact on American companies, is the new normal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] "Unprecedented stability and growth" amidst a market collapse and a trade war? That's, uh, quite the optimistic take, B.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unprecedented stability and growth amidst a market collapse and a trade war? That's, uh, quite the optimistic take, B.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? A real head-scratcher. What a wild economic roller coaster!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? A real head-scratcher. What a wild economic roller coaster!
